stream_context.summary: Kaze worked on the 'Bozo's Oil Rig' level, focusing on implementing and debugging a 'wet cement' feature where Mario leaves decals. The stream featured a live, real-time collaboration with his partner Zeina to create a new worker Koopa character model and ended with Kaze using ChatGPT to brainstorm a thematic redesign for the Tox Box enemy.

development_findings.summary: Kaze reports that the game suffers from numerous crashes when run on original N64 hardware, and debugging these issues is a significant challenge due to a lack of adequate tools.
development_findings.quote: Dude, having a better N64 emulator that tells you why something crashes would be so useful.

development_findings.summary: Kaze implemented a complex decal system for wet cement, which required writing separate code paths to handle the N64's I4 texture format for odd and even pixel offsets.
development_findings.quote: It's because we are using an I4 texture, an I4 texture has 2 pixels per byte, so sometimes when we ground count, we're gonna be at like an odd number of pixels away... there's 2 different types of codes that are running.

development_findings.summary: Kaze developed a highly optimized code snippet for angle calculations (`SIG A10s2S`) which he later learned was comparable to solutions in academic papers, and he is very proud of this achievement.
development_findings.quote: I accidentally made a state-of-the-art programming code, I think... I shared this on a Discord and they sent me a paper... and they were like, oh wait, you did the same thing.

development_findings.summary: Kaze used ChatGPT live on stream to brainstorm ideas for redesigning the Tox Box enemy to fit the oil rig level's theme, settling on a shipping container design.
Kaze confirmed that recent, formal beta testing has led to a significant number of bug fixes and adjustments to the game's early stages.
Kaze casually mentioned that multiplayer is a goal for the project, which influences decisions regarding asset complexity and polygon counts.
development_findings.quote: You still have to keep in mind, Lilaa, that we're gonna try and do multiplayer.

development_findings.summary: The overworld will feature a global coin system allowing players to buy power-ups (as a difficulty-assist option), donate to characters to visually evolve the overworld, and purchase a Yoshi coin.

context_findings.summary: Kaze does not follow a strict coding style, prioritizing functional code over stylistic conventions and focusing on learning to deal with compiler quirks.
context_findings.quote: My motto, my mantra is that if the compiler doesn't see a difference, I also don't see a difference. So code style is just not a thing for me.

context_findings.summary: Kaze describes his work ethic as being based on discipline rather than motivation, simply doing the work that needs to be done.
context_findings.quote: I'm not motivated at all, so there's no motivation involved. I just do it. It's really that easy.

context_findings.summary: Kaze expresses a strong preference for focusing on his work and achieving tasks over engaging in social interactions.
context_findings.quote: I just want to not have to deal with all this being a human and asking questions and being social stuff. I just want to get stuff done.

context_findings.summary: Kaze acknowledges that while he earns some money from his work, it's a passion project, as his skills could be more lucrative in other fields.
context_findings.quote: I mean, technically I make a little bit of money from it, but I would make a lot more money if I just did literally anything else with my skills.

context_findings.summary: Kaze believes the 'troll hack' genre is creatively exhausted and that most new ideas are simply miserable to play rather than being fun or innovative.
context_findings.quote: I think every fun and creative troll hack has already been made and there's nothing you can do.

biobak.summary: Kaze and Biobak collaborated on the overworld design, resolving disagreements to establish a system where players use coins to buy power-ups and fund changes to the world.
biobak.quote: I've had some arguments with Biobak and Discord DMs about how to best do this. And I think we've come to a pretty good agreement.

zeina.summary: Zeina collaborated with Kaze live on stream to create a new eye texture for the worker Koopa model after Kaze was unsatisfied with his own attempt.
zeina.quote: I'm just gonna make you a new texture. Yeah, having him look tired and overworked would look pretty good. Give me a sec, I can make this in like under 10 minutes.

zeina.summary: Zeina provided the initial 'butt print' texture used for the wet cement decal feature.
Kaze created a list of needed animations (idle, talk, angry, carrying glass, upset, walk, fall) for the new worker Koopa and assigned the task to Zeina.
Zeina provided Kaze with a full set of Wario's animations, including a 'funny little walk cycle'.

key_stories.title: Debugging the Wet Cement Decal
key_stories.summary: Kaze spent a significant portion of the stream debugging a visual glitch with a decal that appears on wet cement. The problem was traced to the complexities of the N64's 4-bit indexed (I4) texture format, requiring him to write and fix two separate code paths for odd and even pixel alignments.
key_stories.challenge: A decal for Mario's ground pound was rendering incorrectly on a wet cement surface, with visual artifacts appearing depending on Mario's exact position.
key_stories.process: Kaze debugged the issue live, tracing it to the complexities of the N64's I4 texture format, which stores two pixels per byte. He had to write and meticulously correct two separate code paths for odd and even pixel alignments to solve the visual glitch.
key_stories.outcome: After multiple attempts, Kaze identified and fixed bugs in the bitmasking and variable assignments within his code, resulting in a correctly and consistently rendered decal.
key_stories.key_quote: The code for even numbers is malfunctioning right now, which is weird, because the one for odd numbers should be a lot harder to do.

key_stories.title: Live Collaboration on the Worker Koopa
key_stories.summary: When Kaze struggled with the art for a new worker Koopa character, his partner Zeina jumped in to help live on stream. This spontaneous collaboration involved Kaze modeling while Zeina designed a key texture, showcasing their fluid personal and professional dynamic.
key_stories.challenge: The 'Bozo's Oil Rig' level needed a new character to get upset when Mario ruins a patch of wet cement. Kaze modeled a worker Koopa but struggled to create an eye texture that looked suitably 'tired and overworked'.
key_stories.process: Kaze modeled the Koopa and helmet. When his own eye texture failed to meet his vision, Zeina offered to create a replacement. Kaze sent her the file, and she produced a new texture while he finished other parts of the model. They then integrated her texture live on stream.
key_stories.outcome: The team successfully created a new, fully textured character model ready for animation. Kaze immediately compiled a list of required animations and sent it to Zeina to continue the workflow.
key_stories.key_quote: I'm just gonna make you a new texture... Give me a sec, I can make this in like under 10 minutes.
